excerpt: Victorian Gothic fantasy built on the remains of Norman & Roman ruins, with a colourful interior.
detail_description: Cardiff Castle, located in the heart of the city, is a captivating blend of Victorian Gothic architecture and ancient history. Built on the remnants of Norman and Roman ruins, this popular tourist attraction offers visitors a glimpse into its two millennia of history. The castle features a magnificent 12th-century keep and opulent 19th-century Gothic Revival interiors designed by renowned architect William Burges.
name: Cardiff Castle
address: Castle St, Cardiff, CF10 3RB, United Kingdom

excerpt: Archaeological artefacts, art & natural history, plus visiting exhibitions in a grand setting.
detail_description: National Museum Cardiff is a grand setting that houses archaeological artefacts, art, and natural history exhibits. Visitors can also enjoy temporary exhibitions. The museum boasts the largest collection of Impressionist paintings outside of Paris, featuring works by renowned artists like Renoir, Monet, and Pissarro. Additionally, visitors can explore the city's diverse influences and cultures at Cardiff Castle, which dates back to 55 AD and showcases Roman and Norman architecture.
name: National Museum Cardiff
address: Cardiff, CF10 3NP, United Kingdom

excerpt: Riverside home of Welsh rugby union, plus football, speedway & concerts, with daily tours.
detail_description: In the heart of Cardiff, you can experience a mix of culture, history, and sports. Start your day with a visit to the Millennium Centre for an opera performance or explore the Edwardian arcades for some shopping. Indulge in craft brews at The Potted Pig before heading to Principality Stadium to cheer on the rugby team. Don't miss out on free access to impressive Impressionist paintings at the National Museum.
name: Principality Stadium
address: Westgate St, Cardiff, CF10 1NS, United Kingdom

excerpt: Major modern culture venue staging theatre, opera, ballet and music shows, with bars and dining.
detail_description: The Wales Millennium Centre in Cardiff is a leading cultural venue that hosts a diverse range of performances including theatre, opera, ballet, and music shows. It is renowned for its modern facilities and expansive 5-acre grounds. Visitors can enjoy not only the captivating performances but also participate in workshops, educational events, guided tours, and dining/shopping activities. The center's influence extends beyond traditional entertainment as it also hosts literary events and contemporary dance performances.
name: Wales Millennium Centre
address: Bute Pl, Cardiff, CF10 5AL, United Kingdom

excerpt: Open-air history of Welsh life with ancient buildings re-erected and traditional crafters at work.
detail_description: St. Fagans National Museum of History offers a unique open-air experience showcasing the history of Welsh life. Since 1946, the museum has carefully relocated buildings from across Wales to create an immersive historical landscape on the grounds of St Fagans Castle. Visitors can explore a variety of reconstructed structures, including 19th-century ironworkers' cottages, a tannery, bakehouse, village store, schoolhouse, tollhouse from 1771, and more.
name: St. Fagans National Museum of History
address: Cardiff, CF5 6XB, United Kingdom

excerpt: Celebrated urban area featuring a marina, shops & eateries, plus historic buildings & guided tours.
detail_description: Cardiff Bay is a celebrated urban area with a marina, shops, eateries, and historic buildings. It features the Millennium Stadium and Cardiff Arms Park for sports enthusiasts, as well as the interactive Doctor Who Experience at BBC Roath Lock Studios. The dining scene offers easy-going yet superior Welsh ingredients at various restaurants.
name: Cardiff Bay
address: United Kingdom

excerpt: A rambling riverside beauty spot with an arboretum, Victorian gardens, friary ruins and a cafe.
detail_description: Bute Park, located in the heart of Cardiff, is a sprawling riverside beauty spot that offers a mix of historic features and modern amenities. The park boasts an arboretum with 41 Champion trees, as well as Victorian gardens and friary ruins. Recent restoration efforts have enhanced the park with new facilities such as the Bute Park Education Centre, three cafes, woodland balance trail, sculpture trail, fitness trail, and a diverse events program.
name: Bute Park
address: North Rd, Cardiff, CF10 3ER, United Kingdom

excerpt: Family-friendly attraction that aims to teach people about science and motivate them to learn more.
detail_description: Techniquest is a family-friendly science museum in Cardiff that aims to make learning about science fun and engaging for people of all ages. The museum features over 100 interactive exhibits designed to spark curiosity and promote hands-on learning. Visitors can explore the Chemistry zone, where they can create virtual compounds, learn about molecules, and peer into a microscopic world.
name: Techniquest
address: Stuart St, Cardiff, CF10 5BW, United Kingdom

excerpt: Opened in 1891, this Victorian shopping mall on 2 levels houses an array of merchants & food stalls.
detail_description: The Cardiff Market, a Victorian shopping mall with two levels, has been a vibrant part of the city since the 18th century. The market is filled with merchants and food stalls, offering a variety of local culinary delights such as Welsh cakes cooked on cast iron griddles. The historic structure features a soaring glass roof and exudes a friendly atmosphere. In addition to exploring the market, visitors can also enjoy nearby attractions like the National Museum Cardiff and indulge in street food at Cardiff Indoor Market.
name: The Cardiff Market
address: Cardiff, CF10 1AU, United Kingdom

excerpt: Medieval place of worship with a 10th-century Celtic cross and a triptych painted by D.G. Rossetti.
detail_description: Llandaff Cathedral, located in Cardiff, is a medieval place of worship with a rich history dating back to the 10th century. The cathedral features a 10th-century Celtic cross and a triptych painted by D.G. Rossetti. Built in the 1300s on the ruins of an earlier structure, it boasts an impressive 15th-century tower and an exquisite fully-restored 18th-century Italian temple with rare religious sculptures and artifacts.
name: Llandaff Cathedral
address: Cathedral Cl, Cardiff, CF5 2LA, United Kingdom

excerpt: Water course built for the 2012 Olympics, with rafting & river-boarding on simulated surges.
detail_description: Cardiff International White Water is a thrilling water course constructed for the 2012 Olympics, offering activities like rafting and river-boarding on simulated surges. Situated in Cardiff Bay's sports village, this facility provides diverse experiences for both professionals and amateurs. The 250-meter course can be tailored to accommodate various levels of expertise, from family-friendly rafting to intense canoe or kayak adventures.
name: Cardiff International White Water
address: Watkiss Way, Cardiff, CF11 0SY, United Kingdom

excerpt: Modern harbor barrier, featuring locks & an embankment with bike paths, a playground & picnic areas.
detail_description: Cardiff Bay Barrage, also known as Morglawdd Bae Caerdydd, is a modern harbor barrier that spans 1.1km along the Cardiff Bay. This engineering marvel was created through a Â£220 million project and features locks, sluice gates, bridges, and a dedicated fish pass. The landscaped embankment offers picturesque picnic spots and stunning views of the British Channel from pay-per-view telescopes.
name: Cardiff Bay Barrage
address: Queen Alexandra House, Cargo Rd, Cardiff Bay, CF10 4LY, United Kingdom

detail_description: Located just outside of Cardiff in the village of Tongwynlais, Castell Coch is a 19th-century castle built in the Gothic Revival style. Despite its relatively recent construction, it dates back to the 13th century and is often described as a fairy tale castle. The interior is beautifully decorated and furnished, appealing to those enchanted by Disney Princess aesthetics.
name: Castell Coch
address: Cardiff, CF15 7JS, UK

excerpt: Former 19th-century church with a cafe, a gallery & bay views, plus regular concerts & arts events.
detail_description: The Norwegian Church Arts Centre, located in Cardiff Bay, is a historic 19th-century church that has been transformed into a vibrant cultural hub. Founded in 1868 by Herman Lunde of Oslo, it served as a center for Scandinavian religion and culture, providing seafarers with a place to relax and connect with their heritage. Today, the center hosts regular concerts and arts events while offering stunning views of the waterfront.
name: Norwegian Church Arts Centre
address: Bay, Norwegian Church Arts Centre, Harbour Dr, Cardiff CF10 4PA, United Kingdom

excerpt: Popular gathering place on the water offering an array of restaurants, bars, shops & events.
detail_description: Mermaid Quay is a vibrant waterfront destination in Cardiff, Wales, offering a variety of dining, shopping, and entertainment options. The area features a car-free circular trail around Cardiff Bay with stunning views and a chic skyline. Visitors can explore the Cardiff Bay Barrage, marina, and the bustling atmosphere at Mermaid Quay with its cozy spots for refreshments.
name: Mermaid Quay
address: Cardiff, CF10 5BZ, UK

excerpt: Embracing the southern half of Roath Park Lake, the tranquil Roath Park neighbourhood is a quiet, tree-lined residential area popular with families. Waterfront trails and picnic areas draw students from nearby Cardiff Metropolitan University. A sunroom, tearoom and pavilion retain a Victorian feel in Roath Park botanical gardens. A commercial pocket lies at the junction of Maryport Road and Brandreth Road.
detail_description: Roath Park is a serene residential area located around the southern part of Roath Park Lake, attracting families and students from Cardiff Metropolitan University. The neighborhood features waterfront trails, picnic spots, and a Victorian-style sunroom, tearoom, and pavilion within its botanical gardens. Additionally, there is a commercial area at the junction of Maryport Road and Brandreth Road.
name: Roath Park
address: Cardiff, UK

excerpt: Protected wetlands area & bird habitat with a freshwater lake, boardwalks & viewing platforms.
detail_description: Cardiff Bay Wetlands Reserve is a secluded and protected area that offers a peaceful escape from the city's hustle and bustle. It features a freshwater lake, boardwalks, and viewing platforms that provide excellent vantage points for observing the diverse bird population. This hidden gem is perfect for families, offering kids the opportunity to run around and learn about nature through informative signs.
name: Cardiff Bay Wetlands Reserve
address: Windsor Terrace, Cardiff, UK

excerpt: Victorian variety theatre featuring top names in short-run drama, musical, plays and shows.
detail_description: The New Theatre, located in Cardiff, is a Victorian variety theatre that hosts a wide range of entertainment including short-run dramas, musicals, and plays. Situated on the corner of Park Place, it has been a prominent venue in Cardiff for many years. The theater has showcased everything from Shakespeare plays to performances by iconic figures like Sarah Bernhardt and Laurel and Hardy. It continues to be a popular destination for those seeking classy theater experiences in the Welsh capital.
name: New Theatre
address: Park Pl, Cardiff, CF10 3LN, United Kingdom

excerpt: Cardiff is the capital and largest city of Wales. Cardiff had a population of 372,089 in 2022 and forms a principal area officially known as the City and County of Cardiff. The city is the eleventh largest in the United Kingdom. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Cardiff, the capital and largest city of Wales, is a vibrant destination with a population of over 370,000. As Europe's youngest capital, it offers a blend of history and modernity. Once a major coal industry hub, Cardiff has transformed into a thriving city known for its arts scene, unique shops, and lively nightlife.
name: Cardiff
address: United Kingdom

excerpt: Modern Welsh National Assembly building with transparent walls & an undulating wood roof.
detail_description: The Senedd is a striking modern building that serves as the Welsh National Assembly, offering transparent walls and a distinctive undulating wood roof. Overlooking Cardiff Bay, it stands as one of the city's most remarkable contemporary architectural landmarks. Opened in 2006 by Queen Elizabeth II and renowned architect Lord Richard Rogers, this public building is positioned alongside the Pierhead on the waterfront. Visitors can freely explore The Senedd seven days a week to witness democracy in action or observe debates from the public gallery.
name: The Senedd
address: Senedd, Pierhead St, Cardiff CF99 1SN, United Kingdom

excerpt: City history given a modern makeover with interactive exhibits in a grand Old Library building.
detail_description: The Museum of Cardiff, also known as the 'Cardiff Story Museum,' is housed in a grand Old Library building and offers interactive exhibits that provide a modern perspective on the city's history. Established in 1905, this museum boasts impressive collections, including art dating back to before the 16th century. Visitors can explore diverse works such as French and Post Impressionist pieces, 18th-century Chinese Porcelain, traditional Welsh carvings, silver, sculptures, textiles, and ceramics.
name: Museum of Cardiff
address: The Old Library, The Hayes, St Davids Centre, Cardiff CF10 1BH, United Kingdom

excerpt: Wall running along Bute Park topped with 15 animal sculptures designed in 1866 by William Burges.
detail_description: The Animal Wall, located in Cardiff's Bute Park, is a unique and iconic landmark featuring 15 animal sculptures designed by William Burges in 1866. It took 50 years to complete the wall, with the final sculptures added in the 1930s. The sculptures depict a variety of exotic and familiar animals such as hyenas, baboons, anteaters, lions, beavers, and vultures.
name: Animal Wall
address: 11 Castle St, Cardiff, CF10 1BJ, United Kingdom

excerpt: Modern home of professional football club Cardiff City, hosting matches July-May, plus other events.
detail_description: Cardiff City Stadium is the modern home of Cardiff City Football Club, hosting matches and various events throughout the year. It offers premium conference and event facilities with customizable layouts and contemporary amenities. The stadium is conveniently located near beautiful beaches, just a short distance from Cardiff. Additionally, it's easily accessible from mainland European cities via Cardiff International Airport. The venue provides a fantastic atmosphere for families and visitors can also explore nearby live music venues and art hubs in the bustling city center.
name: Cardiff City Stadium
address: Leckwith Rd, Cardiff, CF11 8AZ, United Kingdom

excerpt: Leisure and entertainment centre with restaurants, a cinema, bowling alley, casino and health club.
detail_description: Located in Cardiff Bay, The Red Dragon Centre is a vibrant leisure and entertainment complex offering a variety of attractions. Visitors can enjoy an international food court with diverse cuisine options, a 4D cinema, bowling alley, casino, health club, and amusement arcades. The center also features an ice-cream parlour and numerous restaurants. It's a popular destination for families with activities to keep everyone entertained from early morning until late at night.
name: The Red Dragon Centre
address: Hemingway Rd, Cardiff, CF10 4JY, United Kingdom

excerpt: St. Fagans is an affluent village on the cityâs outskirts, known for St. Fagans Castle. This Elizabethan manor has extensive gardens, with fountains, the Italian Garden and a rosery. Also within its grounds, the open-air St. Fagans National Museum of History showcases historic buildings relocated from across Wales, including a farm, a tannery, mills and a chapel. The surrounding countryside is popular with walkers.
detail_description: St. Fagans, located on the outskirts of the city, is a charming village renowned for its historic attractions. The centerpiece is St. Fagans Castle, an Elizabethan manor surrounded by extensive gardens featuring fountains and the Italian Garden. Within its grounds lies the open-air St. Fagans National Museum of History, which displays a collection of historic buildings from various parts of Wales, including a farm, tannery, mills, and chapel.
name: St Fagans
address: Cardiff, UK

detail_description: The Pierhead Building, constructed in the late 1800s as the Bute Dock Company headquarters, stands as a prominent landmark in Wales. This terracotta glazed red brick structure is an architectural marvel with its Gothic-style gargoyles and chimneys, and intricately-carved friezes. It has been repurposed into an exhibition building and museum while retaining its historical significance.
name: Pierhead Building
address: Cardiff, CF10 4PZ, United Kingdom

detail_description: The Taff Trail is a 55-mile path that follows the River Taff from Cardiff Bay to Brecon, offering a peaceful escape from city life. It's perfect for walking or cycling, with nextbike rental locations available in the city center. The trail passes by various attractions and landmarks, including the stunning Castle Coch. Visitors can enjoy beautiful scenery and encounter fellow walkers, cyclists, and dog owners along the way.
name: Taff Trail
address: Taff's Well, Cardiff, CF15 7PB, United Kingdom

excerpt: Massive Victorian park with lake, botanic garden, adventure playground, cafe and sports facilities.
detail_description: Roath Park is a grand Victorian park featuring a vast lake, botanical garden, adventure playground, cafe, and sports facilities. The park encompasses a botanical garden, an expansive lake with an old memorial called the lighthouse, a play park, woodland areas, and a wild garden. Visitors can also explore the conservatory housing unique plants and fish. It's located near Wellfield and Albany Road and has been cherished by locals since 1894.
name: Roath Park
address: Lake Rd W, Cardiff, CF23 5PA, United Kingdom

detail_description: Senedd, the home of the Welsh Parliament in Cardiff, is a remarkable and accessible symbol of Welsh democracy. The building reflects the values of transparency and participation, offering free entry to visitors. It features event spaces that promote community engagement and progressive ideals. The Victorian arcades nearby provide an opportunity for unique shopping experiences with independent businesses. Visitors praise the knowledgeable guides and friendly security staff, making it a must-visit for those interested in understanding how democracy functions in Wales.
name: Senedd
address: Cardiff, CF99 1NA, United Kingdom

excerpt: Social space & cultural center featuring international art, performances & films, plus a cafe.
detail_description: Chapter Arts Centre is a vibrant cultural hub in Cardiff, offering a diverse range of international art, performances, and films. The center also features a cozy cafe for visitors to relax and enjoy some refreshments. In addition to its artistic offerings, Cardiff boasts an array of entertainment options and dining experiences. From the Wales Millennium Centre's lively shows to the sophisticated theater productions at The New Theatre, there's something for everyone.
name: Chapter Arts Centre
address: Market Rd, Cardiff, CF5 1QE, United Kingdom

detail_description: Cardiff International Pool & Gym is a modern facility offering an impressive 50m Olympic swimming pool, leisure pool, and gym. The leisure pool features twisting slides, inflatables, a lazy river, and water fountains for family fun. Parents can relax in the health suite while kids enjoy the pool. Swimming lessons are available on weekends with limited access to slides during term-time weekdays. The space bowl and water flumes offer thrilling experiences for visitors of all ages.
name: Cardiff International Pool & Gym
address: Olympian Dr, Cardiff, CF11 0JS, United Kingdom

detail_description: Roald Dahl Plass, situated in Cardiff Bay, is a spacious public square that houses various attractions such as the Wales Millennium Centre and the Norwegian Church. It's a vibrant hub for live music and entertainment, making it an ideal spot to unwind and immerse yourself in the lively ambiance of Cardiff Bay.
name: Roald Dahl Plass
address: Cardiff, UK

excerpt: Modern 2,000 seat concert hall hosting ballet, orchestras and mainstream performances.
detail_description: St David's Hall, located in the heart of Cardiff, is a modern concert hall with a seating capacity of 2,000. It hosts a variety of performances including ballet, orchestral concerts, mainstream music events and theatrical productions. The venue is renowned for its architectural design and serves as one of the leading centers for musical excellence in Wales. Throughout the year, it presents major music festivals such as the Welsh Proms and the Singer of the World competition.
name: St David's Hall
address: 9-11 The Hayes, St Davids Centre, Cardiff CF10 1AH, United Kingdom

detail_description: Aqua Park Cardiff is a thrilling floating water park in Cardiff Bay, offering an action-packed experience with inflatable structures like slides, climbing walls, monkey bars, and trampolines. It's a popular choice for group activities such as stag and hen dos or family outings. Suitable for kids aged eight and up, the park provides an exhilarating open water experience with scenic bay views. Whether it's sunny or not, visitors can slip, slide, and splash their way through this unique attraction.
name: Aqua Park Cardiff
address: Lakes Country Park, Aqua Park Cardiff, Cosmeston, Lavernock Rd, Penarth CF64 5UY, United Kingdom

detail_description: BBC Cymru Wales, located in the new headquarters at Central Square in Cardiff city centre, is the hub of broadcasting in Wales. It houses TV and radio studios and is responsible for producing well-known BBC dramas like Dr Who, Sherlock, and His Dark Materials. The BBC Wales tour offers an inside look at the radio and TV production process. Visitors are guided by a friendly and knowledgeable team through various studios, including the BBC Wales today studio.
name: BBC Tours
address: 3 Central Square, Cardiff, CF10 1FT, United Kingdom

excerpt: Audio tours of a grand 19th-century castle built in the gothic-revival style & surrounded by woods.
detail_description: Castell Coch is a stunning 19th-century Gothic Revival castle located in South Wales, surrounded by picturesque woods. It's often described as a fairytale turreted retreat and is considered one of the most beautiful castles in Cardiff. The interiors are equally impressive and have been restored and maintained by Cadw. Visitors can enjoy audio tours to learn about the castle's history and details, while artists in residence display their work on-site.
name: Castell Coch
address: Cardiff, CF15 7JS, United Kingdom

detail_description: The National Museum is located in a grand Portland-stone structure and aims to showcase the history of Wales while highlighting its global significance. Its well-designed exhibits guide visitors through the natural history, as well as the artistic and cultural heritage of the country. The museum also boasts an impressive collection of artwork from renowned French and European Impressionist and Post-Impressionist artists.
name: National Museum
address: Cardiff, United Kingdom

detail_description: The college offers a rich and diverse calendar of free events, including musical performances, art shows, and theater productions. The building is quite impressive too!
name: Royal Welsh College of Music & Drama
address: North Rd, Cardiff, CF10 3ER, United Kingdom

excerpt: First built in the 12th century, this church features a classic tower with battlements & 10 bells.
detail_description: St John The Baptist City Parish Church, located in the heart of Cardiff city center, is a historic Anglican church with a rich heritage dating back to the 12th century. The church features a classic tower with battlements and is adorned with ten bells. Its golden-pinnacled 15th-century tower offers breathtaking views of Cardiff Castle.
name: St John The Baptist City Parish Church
address: St John St, Cardiff, CF10 1GJ, United Kingdom

detail_description: Nestled in Cardiff Bay, the iconic Pierhead Building stands out with its striking redbrick clock tower and Victorian Gothic architecture. Constructed in 1897 for the Bute Dock Company, this Grade listed structure is a testament to Cardiff's rich maritime history. Inside, visitors can explore engaging exhibitions that delve into Welsh history, including artifacts from the medieval fight for independence. The Pierhead also serves as a vibrant venue for public events like art shows and discussions, making it a hub of cultural activity.
name: Pierhead
address: Pierhead St, Cardiff, CF10 4PZ, United Kingdom

excerpt: Retail chain buying & selling video games & digital devices, including mobile phones & laptops.
detail_description: St Davidâs Dewi Sant is a renowned shopping center located in the city center, offering a wide range of retail options including video games and digital devices. The area also provides convenient parking options for visitors, making it easy to explore nearby attractions such as Cardiff Castle and the Millennium Stadium. St Davidâs Dewi Sant is situated in the picturesque city of St Davids, known for its historical significance as well as its modern appeal.
name: St Davidâs Dewi Sant
address: St Davids Dewi Sant, Bridge St, St Davids Centre, Cardiff CF10 2EF, United Kingdom

excerpt: Stately 1906 building carved from Portland stone & designed in the English Renaissance style.
detail_description: City Hall in Cardiff, UK is a magnificent 1906 building made of Portland stone and designed in the English Renaissance style. It's a significant landmark located at the heart of the city, featuring impressive architecture, a large domed roof, marble hall, regular exhibitions, and period features. The grand building has been recently restored and is synonymous with the city. It hosts major events and festivals and offers indoor photo opportunities for weddings.
name: City Hall
address: King Edward VII Ave, Cardiff, CF10 3ND, UK

excerpt: Penarth is a town and community in the Vale of Glamorgan, Wales, approximately 3 miles south of Cardiff city centre on the west shore of the Severn Estuary at the southern end of Cardiff Bay. Wikipedia.
detail_description: Penarth, a charming town and community in the Vale of Glamorgan, Wales, is located just 3 miles south of Cardiff city center on the west shore of the Severn Estuary. The town offers a delightful mix of sea, sand, food, shopping, and a historic pier. It's known for its close-knit community and vibrant atmosphere.
name: Penarth
address: United Kingdom

detail_description: Parc Cefn Onn is a charming woodland park situated on the northern outskirts of Cardiff, away from any residential buildings. It was designed in the early 20th century and boasts an array of exotic trees and shrubs, including conifers, rhododendrons, and azaleas. The park holds historical significance as it was laid out by Ernest Albert Prosser and his head gardener Tom Jenkins.
name: Parc Cefn Onn
address: Cardiff, CF14 0EP, United Kingdom

excerpt: Multi-purpose venue for live music and comedy, sports events, banquets, conferences and exhibitions.
detail_description: Utilita Arena Cardiff is a versatile indoor events arena that hosts a wide range of entertainment, including live music concerts by renowned artists like Kylie Minogue and local favorites such as the Manic Street Preachers. The venue also features theatre productions, ice shows, stand-up comedy, sports events, banquets, conferences and exhibitions. With a capacity of 7500 people, it is the second largest music venue in Cardiff.
name: Utilita Arena Cardiff
address: Mary Ann St, Cardiff, CF10 2EQ, United Kingdom

excerpt: Gardens designed in 1906 as a series of outdoor rooms set among lawns, an arboretum and wild garden.
detail_description: Dyffryn Gardens, designed in 1906 by landscape architect Thomas Mawson, offers a series of outdoor rooms set among lawns, an arboretum, and a wild garden. The site is maintained by the National Trust Wales and is known for its Instagrammable flower gardens. Visitors can explore the four houses on the property with behind-the-scenes access granted by staff and volunteers.
name: National Trust - Dyffryn Gardens
address: Duffryn Ln, St Nicholas, Wenvoe, Cardiff CF5 6FZ, United Kingdom

excerpt:
Castle is a community in the centre of Cardiff, Wales. It includes Cardiff city centre as well as the civic buildings of Cathays Park, bordered by the River Taff to the west, the railway to the south and east, Corbett Road to the north.
There is no community council for the area. Wikipedia.
name: Castle
address: Cardiff, UK

excerpt: Stylish fine-dining restaurant run by prison inmates serving dishes made with organic Welsh produce.
detail_description: The Clink Restaurant Cardiff is a stylish fine-dining establishment that offers organic Welsh cuisine prepared and served by prison inmates. As part of The Clink Charity's initiative, the restaurant provides full-time work and extensive training to ex-offenders, aiming to reduce reoffending rates by integrating them into the hospitality industry. Open for breakfast, lunch, afternoon tea, and evening meals on select days, this chic restaurant not only delivers quality food but also supports a meaningful cause.
name: The Clink Restaurant Cardiff
address: HMP, Knox Rd, Cardiff CF24 0UG, United Kingdom

detail_description: Located right on the Cardiff Bay waterfront, the shopping mall Mermaid Quay offers a mix of retail outlets and restaurants. The plaza is popular with locals and tourists alike for its stunning waterfront views.
name: Mermaid Quay
address: Cardiff, CF10 5BZ, United Kingdom

excerpt: Cardiff City Centre is Wales' commercial and leisure hub. Big-name bands perform at the Motorpoint Arena, as well as the riverside Principality Stadium, home of national rugby and football teams. Indie shops are housed in Victorian arcades like the Morgan Quarter, and Castle Arcade at the foot of Cardiff Castle, while chain brands populate the modern St. David's Dewi Sant mall. Eclectic eateries line St. Mary Street.
detail_description: Cardiff City Centre is the bustling heart of Wales, offering a mix of commerce and entertainment. The area boasts renowned music venues like Motorpoint Arena and Principality Stadium, which hosts national rugby and football events. Visitors can explore Victorian arcades such as Morgan Quarter and Castle Arcade near Cardiff Castle, alongside modern shopping at St. David's Dewi Sant mall.
name: City Centre
address: Cardiff, UK
